abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Power Project
            is rated as satisfactory. The major lessons learned is that
            up-front commitments and support for sector reform, with
            articulated ownership by all parties concerned, facilitates
            the process of commercialization and power sector
            restructuring. The second lesson learned is that importance
            of embracing difficult sector policy issues within the
            overall macro dialogue through structural adjustment
            operations. This brought into sharp focus the potential
            impact of the YTL transaction on the economy and power
            sector, and prompted support for actions to redress tariff
            levels. This also led to the adoption of a much more
            transparent environment for private sector participation in
            the power sector. The third lesson learned is the need to be
            very specific concerning whether or not to include optional
            items in bid evaluations. Fourthly, the absence of a
            Standard Bidding Document for Supply and Installation of
            Plant and Equipment, which was introduced about mid-term of
            project, is partly the cause for some of the procurement
            delays encountered by the Project. Fifthly, Zimbabwe
            Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA) has set the example that
            a monthly application of an automatic adjustment formula
            helps to underpin its financial viability, at the same time
            minimizing political interference. Additional measures will
            be needed to enable ZESA repay its large accumulated foreign
            debt brought about by exchange rate and inflation changes.

abstracts.cdata!:
The short-term objectives of the project
            are to: (a) minimize the severity of the power shortage in
            Zimbabwe caused by the recent drought and facilitate
            economic recovery by increasing the performance and
            reliability of the Hwange coal-fired power station,
            Zimbabwe's largest generating station; (b) reduce the
            incidence and severity of power blackouts during the power
            shortage to minimize the economic and social disruption they
            cause. Over the longer term, the project will: (d)
            selectively increase the capacity and reliability of the
            distribution system so as to serve more consumers when the
            power shortage is alleviated; and (e) reduce the unit cost
            of power and power system investment by commercializing the
            power utility, improving the condition of existing power
            facilities, economic power pricing and by short-term
            technical assistance and training. The project consists of:
            (a) operation support, maintenance, spares, and major
            overhaul services and selective equipment upgrades for
            Hwange Power Station; (b) distribution system reinforcement
            through the installation of additional transformer capacity,
            line uprating, and installation of capacitors and load
            shedding devices; (c) training and technical assistance; (d)
            provision of workshop equipment and maintenance vehicles;
            and (e) completion of Zimbabwe Electricity Supply
            Authority's management information system.
